title: 1196-A
statement: A. Three Piles of Candiestime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputAlice and Bob have received three big piles of candies as a gift. Now they want to divide these candies as fair as possible. To do this, Alice takes one pile of candies, then Bob takes one of the other two piles. The last pile is split between Alice and Bob as they want: for example, it is possible that Alice takes the whole pile, and Bob gets nothing from it.After taking the candies from the piles, if Alice has more candies than Bob, she discards some candies so that the number of candies she has is equal to the number of candies Bob has. Of course, Bob does the same if he has more candies.Alice and Bob want to have as many candies as possible, and they plan the process of dividing candies accordingly. Please calculate the maximum number of candies Alice can have after this division process (of course, Bob will have the same number of candies).You have to answer $$$q$$$ independent queries.Let's see the following example: $$$[1, 3, 4]$$$. Then Alice can choose the third pile, Bob can take the second pile, and then the only candy from the first pile goes to Bob — then Alice has $$$4$$$ candies, and Bob has $$$4$$$ candies.Another example is $$$[1, 10, 100]$$$. Then Alice can choose the second pile, Bob can choose the first pile, and candies from the third pile can be divided in such a way that Bob takes $$$54$$$ candies, and Alice takes $$$46$$$ candies. Now Bob has $$$55$$$ candies, and Alice has $$$56$$$ candies, so she has to discard one candy — and after that, she has $$$55$$$ candies too.InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$q$$$ ($$$1 \\le q \\le 1000$$$) — the number of queries. Then $$$q$$$ queries follow.The only line of the query contains three integers $$$a, b$$$ and $$$c$$$ ($$$1 \\le a, b, c \\le 10^{16}$$$) — the number of candies in the first, second and third piles correspondingly.OutputPrint $$$q$$$ lines. The $$$i$$$-th line should contain the answer for the $$$i$$$-th query — the maximum number of candies Alice can have after the division, if both Alice and Bob act optimally (of course, Bob will have the same number of candies).ExampleInput4 1 3 4 1 10 100 10000000000000000 10000000000000000 10000000000000000 23 34 45Output4 55 15000000000000000 51

processed.result:
You are given three piles of candies with $a$, $b$, and $c$ candies respectively. Two players take turns taking one pile of candies. The player who takes the last pile can split it however they want.  After taking candies, if a player has more candies than the other player, they discard some candies so that they have the same number as the other player.

What is the maximum number of candies a player can have after this process?

You have to solve this problem for $q$ different sets of candies.

You are given three piles of items. Two players take turns choosing a pile. After all piles are taken, the remaining pile is split evenly.  If a player has more items than the other, they discard some to have an equal amount.  What is the maximum number of items a player can have?
